How can real-time data analytics be performed in MATLAB using streaming data?

% create a session object for data acquisition

% add a voltage input channel to the session

% configure the sampling rate and duration
s.Rate = 1000; % samples per second
s.DurationInSeconds = 10;
% define a callback function to process data as it is acquired
s.NotifyWhenDataAvailableExceeds = s.Rate; % notify every second
s.IsContinuous = true; % acquire data continuously
s.addlistener('DataAvailable', @(src, event) process_data(event.TimeStamps, event.Data));
% start the data acquisition
startBackground(s);
% define the data processing function
function process_data(time, data)
    % perform real-time analytics on the streaming data here
    % e.g., calculate mean, max, min, etc.
end
This code will continuously acquire data from an analog input channel, and every second it will call the process_data function to perform real-time analytics on the streaming data. You can customize the analytics performed in the process_data function based on your specific needs.

| Pepper           | 2                |

| Egg yolks        | 2                |
| Egg whites       | 3                |
1. Preheat oven to 375°F.
2. Melt butter in a saucepan over medium heat. Whisk in flour until smooth. Gradually add milk, salt, and pepper, stirring constantly until mixture comes to a boil. Cook and stir for 2 minutes or until thickened. Remove from heat.

4. In a large bowl, beat egg whites until stiff peaks form. With a rubber spatula, fold a fourth of the egg whites into cheese mixture until no white streaks remain. Fold in remaining egg whites.
5. Transfer to a greased 1-1/2-qt. soufflé dish. Bake for 30-35 minutes or until puffed and golden brown. Serve immediately. Enjoy!

prompt:
How can I use R to simulate a thermodynamic process and generate a sentence based on the results?
Here's some sample R code to get started:
set.seed(123)
n <- 1000 # number of iterations
T <- numeric(n) # temperature
V <- numeric(n) # volume
P <- numeric(n) # pressure
# initial conditions
T[1] <- 300 # Kelvin
V[1] <- 1 # m^3
P[1] <- 1 # atm
# simulation loop
for(i in 2:n) {
  # calculate new temperature, volume, and pressure based on thermodynamic equations
  T[i] <- T[i-1] + rnorm(1, 0, 5)
  V[i] <- V[i-1] + rnorm(1, 0, 0.1)
  P[i] <- (n/i) * (T[i] * V[i]) / 8.314 # ideal gas law
  
  # check for negative volume or pressure
  if(V[i] < 0) V[i] <- abs(V[i])
  if(P[i] < 0) P[i] <- abs(P[i])
}
# generate sentence based on final results
final_T <- round(T[n], 2)
final_V <- round(V[n], 2)
final_P <- round(P[n], 2)
paste("After", n, "iterations of a thermodynamic process, the final temperature was", final_T, "K, the final volume was", final_V, "m^3, and the final pressure was", final_P, "atm.")
